newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: National, NZ First coalition talks start.
newsitem.headline: National, NZ First coalition talks start.

text.p: Negotiating teams from the conservative National Party and nationalist New Zealand First began their first meeting on Monday to hammer out an agenda and procedure for coalition-building talks.
The venue for the meeting, in parliament's library building, was not released in advance, but New Zealand First leader Winston Peters denied there was any secrecy surrounding it.
"We will beginning discussions on matters of process before we get down to substantive matters and that will involve issues like agenda..." Peters said.
He said the meeting would take as long as was needed to conclude those matters.
New Zealand First, which holds the balance of power after on inconclusive general election on October 12, will open negotiations with the main opposition Labour Party on Wednesday.
"We have signalled to both Labour and National we are interested in conducting the negotiations fairly without favouring either side," Peters said.
He predicted the meeting would "go very well" and reiterated his election-night appeal to the media for patience.
Prime Minister Jim Bolger, who is leading National's team, said the meeting was "the beginning".
